This field allows you to provide a free-text explanation or comment related to the current status of the measure. It is especially useful for elaborating on delays, obstacles, changes, or progress updates that are not captured by the status field alone.

ğŸš© Tips

- Explain any unexpected delays, re-scoping, or need for help.
- Describe remaining work, risks, or dependencies.

This field is used to assign the person responsible for implementing the measure. The dropdown menu shows active Dmaze users by their full name (first and last). Assigning a responsible person is required before the measure can be set to implementation.

To ensure clear accountability for executing and reporting on the measure.

 

ğŸ‘¥ Roles

- Measure Creator or Initiator: Selects the responsible person from the list.
- Responsible User: Accepts or declines the task and updates progress.

 

ğŸ’¡ Why this matters

Assigning responsibility ensures that the measure is actively followed up. It also enables system-generated email notifications, improving communication and accountability.

 

ğŸš© Tips

- Choose someone with the right skills, role, and authority to carry out the measure.
- A valid email address is required to receive notifications â€“ a warning icon will appear if the selected user is missing this.
- The responsible person will receive an email when the measure is moved to implementation status, asking them to accept or decline the task.

 

ğŸ“Œ Examples

fields.label: Responsible

fields.description:
This field shows the current status of the measure (task or action), reflecting its progress from creation to closure. The status updates automatically based on user decisions and system events, and determines when a measure is considered closed. Email notifications are triggered at key decision points to keep responsible parties informed.

 

ğŸ¯ Purpose

To track and manage the lifecycle of a measure, ensure all stakeholders are aligned, and maintain control over implementation, acceptance, and completion.

 

ğŸ‘¥ Roles

**Initiator** (e.g. process owner, risk owner, team lead):  
- Creates the measure and chooses between implementing, acknowledging it already exists, or cancelling it.  
- Assigns a responsible person and sets a due date if implementation is selected.  
- Approves, cancels, or rejects the completed measure.

**Measure Responsible**:  
- Accepts, declines, cancels, or closes the measure as â€œExistingâ€ or â€œDo not implementâ€.  
- Updates progress status during implementation.  
- Marks the measure as complete for approval.

 

ğŸ’¡ Why this matters

A well-defined status lifecycle ensures consistent handling of all measures, enables transparency, automates follow-up through email notifications, and defines clear closure criteria. It supports accountability across different roles.

 

ğŸš© Tips

- Make sure 'Responsible' and 'Due Date' are filled in before starting implementation.  
- Use â€œExistsâ€ only when the action is already implemented and verifiable.  
- Measures are considered **closed** when status is: **Existing**, **Cancelled**, or **Completed (100%) (approved)**.  
- Emails are automatically sent when a measure is assigned, declined, completed, cancelled, or approved.  
- If a measure is rejected after completion, the responsible person must continue working until it can be approved.

 

ğŸ“Œ Examples

- A user creates a measure and selects â€œDo not implementâ€. The status becomes **Cancelled**, and the measure is closed.  
- A responsible user accepts a measure, completes it, and the initiator approves it. The status becomes **Completed (100%) (approved)**, and the process is complete.

ğŸ’¬ **Want to see the actual lifecycle for this measure?**  
Click the **Change log** button in the top-right corner above this field to view the full step-by-step history, including who made each change and when.

 

ğŸ“Š Status Lifecycle Overview

1. **Measure is created** â†’ `Identified (pending decision)` *(System)*  
2. **Initiator clicks**:
   - *Implement* â†’ Requires Responsible + Due date â†’ `To be implemented (pending accept)` *(email sent to Responsible)*  
   - *Exists* â†’ `Existing` *(Closed)*  
   - *Do not implement* â†’ `Cancelled` *(Closed)*
3. **Responsible user chooses**:
   - *Decline* â†’ `To be implemented (declined)` *(email sent to Initiator)*  
   - *Accept* â†’ `In progress (not started)` â†’ Access to:
     - `In progress (25%)`, `In progress (50%)`, `In progress (75%)`
     - `Completed (100%) (for approval)` *(email sent to Initiator)*  
     - *Cancel* â†’ `In progress (cancelled)` *(email sent to Initiator)*  
   - *Exists* â†’ `Existing` *(Closed)*  
   - *Do not implement* â†’ `Cancelled` *(Closed)*
4. **Initiator chooses**:
   - *Approve* â†’ `Completed (100%) (approved)` *(Closed)*  
   - *Reject* â†’ `Completed (100%) (not approved)` *(measure reopens)*  
   - *Cancel* â†’ `In progress (cancelled)` *(Closed)*

 

âœ… When is a measure considered closed?

- `Existing`  
- `Cancelled`  
- `Completed (100%) (approved)`

 

âš ï¸ Note: The list of selectable status options and transitions may be customised by your organisationâ€™s administrator to reflect internal processes and governance.

This field allows you to add one or more URLs (links) to internal or external resources that provide additional context, reference material, or supporting information for this record. It is intended for linking to web-based resources â€” not to other records within Dmaze (for that, use the Related to field). When adding a link, you can also provide a human-readable description (link title) to clearly indicate what the link is for. This makes it easier for others to understand the purpose of the link without having to click on it.

 

ğŸ¯ Purpose

To give users direct access to relevant online content that supports understanding, implementation, or verification of the record.

 

ğŸ‘¥ Roles

- Record Owner or Contributor: Adds and maintains the list of links.
- Participants and Reviewers: Use the links to access additional details, evidence, or background.

 

ğŸ’¡ Why this matters

Links provide instant access to supporting materials, reducing the need for manual searches and ensuring all stakeholders work from the same trusted sources. Where possible, use this field instead of attaching documents directly â€” linked resources respect existing access permissions and security controls on the hosting platform.

 

ğŸš© Tips

- You can add multiple links.
- Use complete, valid, and accessible URLs.
- Always provide a short, meaningful description for each link so users know what to expect before clicking.
- Regularly check and update links to avoid broken or outdated references.
- If linking to documents that require controlled access, ensure permissions are properly managed on the hosting platform.
- Prefer using links instead of attachments for resources that are maintained elsewhere â€” this helps ensure everyone always sees the latest version.

 

ğŸ“Œ Examples

- Data Protection Policy â€“ https://intranet.example.com/policies/data-protection
- Project 42 Overview â€“ https://projects.example.com/initiative-42
- Regulatory Guidelines â€“ Section 5 â€“ https://regulator.example.org/guidelines/section-5
